trans-unit.source: What is a Network Access Control List (ACL)?
trans-unit.target: What is a Network Access Control List (ACL)?

trans-unit.source: Learn about ACLs
trans-unit.target: Learn about ACLs

trans-unit.source: What is a Network Access Control List (ACLs)?
trans-unit.target: What is a Network Access Control List (ACLs)?

trans-unit.source: A Network Access Control List (ACL) is a security enhancement available for your Azure deployment.
trans-unit.target: A Network Access Control List (ACL) is a security enhancement available for your Azure deployment.

trans-unit.source: An ACL provides the ability to selectively permit or deny traffic for a virtual machine endpoint.
trans-unit.target: An ACL provides the ability to selectively permit or deny traffic for a virtual machine endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This packet filtering capability provides an additional layer of security.
trans-unit.target: This packet filtering capability provides an additional layer of security.

trans-unit.source: You can specify network ACLs for endpoints only.
trans-unit.target: You can specify network ACLs for endpoints only.

trans-unit.source: You can't specify an ACL for a virtual network or a specific subnet contained in a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You can't specify an ACL for a virtual network or a specific subnet contained in a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to use Network Security Groups (NSGs) instead of ACLs whenever possible.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to use Network Security Groups (NSGs) instead of ACLs whenever possible.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about NSGs, see <link><linkText>What is a Network Security Group?</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about NSGs, see <link><linkText>What is a Network Security Group?</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: ACLs can be configured by using either PowerShell or the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: ACLs can be configured by using either PowerShell or the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: To configure a network ACL by using PowerShell, see <link><linkText>Managing Access Control Lists (ACLs) for Endpoints by using PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To configure a network ACL by using PowerShell, see <link><linkText>Managing Access Control Lists (ACLs) for Endpoints by using PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To configure a network ACL by using the Management Portal, see <link><linkText>How to Set Up Endpoints to a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To configure a network ACL by using the Management Portal, see <link><linkText>How to Set Up Endpoints to a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Using Network ACLs, you can do the following:
trans-unit.target: Using Network ACLs, you can do the following:

trans-unit.source: Selectively permit or deny incoming traffic based on remote subnet IPv4 address range to a virtual machine input endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Selectively permit or deny incoming traffic based on remote subnet IPv4 address range to a virtual machine input endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Blacklist IP addresses
trans-unit.target: Blacklist IP addresses

trans-unit.source: Create multiple rules per virtual machine endpoint
trans-unit.target: Create multiple rules per virtual machine endpoint

trans-unit.source: Specify up to 50 ACL rules per virtual machine endpoint
trans-unit.target: Specify up to 50 ACL rules per virtual machine endpoint

trans-unit.source: Use rule ordering to ensure the correct set of rules are applied on a given virtual machine endpoint (lowest to highest)
trans-unit.target: Use rule ordering to ensure the correct set of rules are applied on a given virtual machine endpoint (lowest to highest)

trans-unit.source: Specify an ACL for a specific remote subnet IPv4 address.
trans-unit.target: Specify an ACL for a specific remote subnet IPv4 address.

trans-unit.source: How ACLs work
trans-unit.target: How ACLs work

trans-unit.source: An ACL is an object that contains a list of rules.
trans-unit.target: An ACL is an object that contains a list of rules.

trans-unit.source: When you create an ACL and apply it to a virtual machine endpoint, packet filtering takes place on the host node of your VM.
trans-unit.target: When you create an ACL and apply it to a virtual machine endpoint, packet filtering takes place on the host node of your VM.

trans-unit.source: This means the traffic from remote IP addresses is filtered by the host node for matching ACL rules instead of on your VM.
trans-unit.target: This means the traffic from remote IP addresses is filtered by the host node for matching ACL rules instead of on your VM.

trans-unit.source: This prevents your VM from spending the precious CPU cycles on packet filtering.
trans-unit.target: This prevents your VM from spending the precious CPU cycles on packet filtering.

trans-unit.source: When a virtual machine is created, a default ACL is put in place to block all incoming traffic.
trans-unit.target: When a virtual machine is created, a default ACL is put in place to block all incoming traffic.

trans-unit.source: However, if an endpoint is created for (port 3389), then the default ACL is modified to allow all inbound traffic for that endpoint.
trans-unit.target: However, if an endpoint is created for (port 3389), then the default ACL is modified to allow all inbound traffic for that endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Inbound traffic from any remote subnet is then allowed to that endpoint and no firewall provisioning is required.
trans-unit.target: Inbound traffic from any remote subnet is then allowed to that endpoint and no firewall provisioning is required.

trans-unit.source: All other ports are blocked for inbound traffic unless endpoints are created for those ports.
trans-unit.target: All other ports are blocked for inbound traffic unless endpoints are created for those ports.

trans-unit.source: Outbound traffic is allowed by default.
trans-unit.target: Outbound traffic is allowed by default.

trans-unit.source: Example Default ACL table
trans-unit.target: Example Default ACL table

trans-unit.target: Rule #

trans-unit.target: Remote Subnet

trans-unit.source: Endpoint
trans-unit.target: Endpoint

trans-unit.source: Permit/Deny
trans-unit.target: Permit/Deny

trans-unit.source: Permit
trans-unit.target: Permit

trans-unit.source: Permit and deny
trans-unit.target: Permit and deny

trans-unit.source: You can selectively permit or deny network traffic for a virtual machine input endpoint by creating rules that specify "permit" or "deny".
trans-unit.target: You can selectively permit or deny network traffic for a virtual machine input endpoint by creating rules that specify "permit" or "deny".

trans-unit.source: It's important to note that by default, when an endpoint is created, all traffic is denied to the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: It's important to note that by default, when an endpoint is created, all traffic is denied to the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: For that reason, it's important to understand how to create permit/deny rules and place them in the proper order of precedence if you want granular control over the network traffic that you choose to allow to reach the virtual machine endpoint.
trans-unit.target: For that reason, it's important to understand how to create permit/deny rules and place them in the proper order of precedence if you want granular control over the network traffic that you choose to allow to reach the virtual machine endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Points to consider:
trans-unit.target: Points to consider:

trans-unit.source: No ACL – By default when an endpoint is created, we permit all for the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: No ACL – By default when an endpoint is created, we permit all for the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Permit - When you add one or more "permit" ranges, you are denying all other ranges by default.
trans-unit.target: Permit - When you add one or more "permit" ranges, you are denying all other ranges by default.

trans-unit.source: Only packets from the permitted IP range will be able to communicate with the virtual machine endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Only packets from the permitted IP range will be able to communicate with the virtual machine endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Deny - When you add one or more "deny" ranges, you are permitting all other ranges of traffic by default.
trans-unit.target: Deny - When you add one or more "deny" ranges, you are permitting all other ranges of traffic by default.

trans-unit.source: Combination of Permit and Deny - You can use a combination of "permit" and "deny" when you want to carve out a specific IP range to be permitted or denied.
trans-unit.target: Combination of Permit and Deny - You can use a combination of "permit" and "deny" when you want to carve out a specific IP range to be permitted or denied.

trans-unit.source: Rules and rule precedence
trans-unit.target: Rules and rule precedence

trans-unit.source: Network ACLs can be set up on specific virtual machine endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Network ACLs can be set up on specific virtual machine endpoints.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can specify a network ACL for an RDP endpoint created on a virtual machine which locks down access for certain IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can specify a network ACL for an RDP endpoint created on a virtual machine which locks down access for certain IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: The table below shows a way to grant access to public virtual IPs (VIPs) of a certain range to permit access for RDP.
trans-unit.target: The table below shows a way to grant access to public virtual IPs (VIPs) of a certain range to permit access for RDP.

trans-unit.source: All other remote IPs are denied.
trans-unit.target: All other remote IPs are denied.

trans-unit.source: We follow a lowest takes precedence rule order.
trans-unit.target: We follow a lowest takes precedence rule order.

trans-unit.source: Multiple rules
trans-unit.target: Multiple rules

trans-unit.source: In the example below, if you want to allow access to the RDP endpoint only from two public IPv4 address ranges (65.0.0.0/8, and 159.0.0.0/8), you can achieve this by specifying two Permit rules.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, if you want to allow access to the RDP endpoint only from two public IPv4 address ranges (65.0.0.0/8, and 159.0.0.0/8), you can achieve this by specifying two Permit rules.

trans-unit.source: In this case, since RDP is created by default for a virtual machine, you may want to lock down access to the RDP port based on a remote subnet.
trans-unit.target: In this case, since RDP is created by default for a virtual machine, you may want to lock down access to the RDP port based on a remote subnet.

trans-unit.source: The example below shows a way to grant access to public virtual IPs (VIPs) of a certain range to permit access for RDP.
trans-unit.target: The example below shows a way to grant access to public virtual IPs (VIPs) of a certain range to permit access for RDP.

trans-unit.source: All other remote IPs are denied.
trans-unit.target: All other remote IPs are denied.

trans-unit.source: This works because network ACLs can be set up for a specific virtual machine endpoint and access is denied by default.
trans-unit.target: This works because network ACLs can be set up for a specific virtual machine endpoint and access is denied by default.

trans-unit.source: Rule order
trans-unit.target: Rule order

trans-unit.source: Because multiple rules can be specified for an endpoint, there must be a way to organize rules in order to determine which rule takes precedence.
trans-unit.target: Because multiple rules can be specified for an endpoint, there must be a way to organize rules in order to determine which rule takes precedence.

trans-unit.source: The rule order specifies precedence.
trans-unit.target: The rule order specifies precedence.

trans-unit.source: Network ACLs follow a lowest takes precedence rule order.
trans-unit.target: Network ACLs follow a lowest takes precedence rule order.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the endpoint on port 80 is selectively granted access to only certain IP address ranges.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the endpoint on port 80 is selectively granted access to only certain IP address ranges.

trans-unit.source: To configure this, we have a deny rule (Rule \# 100) for addresses in the 175.1.0.1/24 space.
trans-unit.target: To configure this, we have a deny rule (Rule \# 100) for addresses in the 175.1.0.1/24 space.

trans-unit.source: A second rule is then specified with precedence 200 that permits access to all other addresses under 175.0.0.0/8.
trans-unit.target: A second rule is then specified with precedence 200 that permits access to all other addresses under 175.0.0.0/8.

trans-unit.source: Example – Rule precedence
trans-unit.target: Example – Rule precedence

trans-unit.source: Permit
trans-unit.target: Permit

trans-unit.source: Network ACLs and load balanced sets
trans-unit.target: Network ACLs and load balanced sets

trans-unit.source: Network ACLs can be specified on a Load balanced set (LB Set) endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Network ACLs can be specified on a Load balanced set (LB Set) endpoint.

trans-unit.source: If an ACL is specified for a LB Set, the Network ACL is applied to all Virtual Machines in that LB Set.
trans-unit.target: If an ACL is specified for a LB Set, the Network ACL is applied to all Virtual Machines in that LB Set.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a LB Set is created with "Port 80" and the LB Set contains 3 VMs, the Network ACL created on endpoint "Port 80" of one VM will automatically apply to the other VMs.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a LB Set is created with "Port 80" and the LB Set contains 3 VMs, the Network ACL created on endpoint "Port 80" of one VM will automatically apply to the other VMs.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Network ACLs and load balanced sets</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Network ACLs and load balanced sets</linkText>
